facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1573 N of 1972 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 3rd February, 1971 of the Gujarat High Court at Ahmedabad in Second Appeal No.639 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1573 N  of 1972. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 3rd February, 1971 of the Gujarat High Court at Ahmedabad in Second Appeal No.639 of 1968.

facts.text: The appellants and the respondent belong to one family with the respondent representing the seniormost branch.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants and the respondent belong to one family. The respondent represents the seniormost branch of the family.

facts.text: The family was granted Patilki Watan in a number of villages, including Solsumbha, in district Thana.

anchor.surface_text: The family was granted Patilki Watan in a number of villages, including Solsumbha, in district Thana. The watan land situated in Solsumbha is the subject matter of the present dispute.

facts.text: The watan land situated in Solsumbha is the subject matter of the present dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The watan land situated in Solsumbha is the subject matter of the present dispute. Under the Bombay Hereditary Offices Act, 1874 the person who actually performs the duty of a hereditary office for the time being is called an officiator.

facts.text: Purshottam, father of the respondent, was the officiator till 1921 when he incurred a disqualification and a deputy was appointed in his place.

anchor.surface_text: Purshottam, father of the respondent, was the officiator till 1921 when, because of a disqualification incurred by him, a deputy was appointed in place of Purshottam.

facts.text: Purshottam died in 1940 and the respondent became the officiator.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of Purshottam in 1940, the respondent became the officiator the branch of the appellants claimed to be ill possession of the watan land in dispute and some other lands under a partition effected in 1914.

facts.text: The branch of the appellants claimed to be in possession of the watan land in dispute under a partition effected in 1914.

anchor.surface_text: the branch of the appellants claimed to be ill possession of the watan land in dispute and some other lands under a partition effected in 1914. In 1944 the respondent moved the government for resumption of the, watan land in dispute which was in possession of the branch of the appellants.

facts.text: In 1944 the respondent moved the government for resumption of the watan land in dispute which was in possession of the branch of the appellants and for delivery of possession.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944 the respondent moved the government for resumption of the, watan land in dispute which was in possession of the branch of the appellants. Prayer was also made by the respondent that he might be delivered possession of the land.

facts.text: The government resumed the land by order dated October 9, 1946 and directed that possession be restored to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The government after some enquiry resumed that land by order dated October 9, 1946 and directed that possession of the same be restored to the respondent.

facts.text: The appellants moved the government for reconsideration of the October 9, 1946 order.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants thereafter moved the government for reconsideration of that order. The government on May 2, 1947 modified its previous order by directing that the. appellants companyld companytinue to retain the possession of the land in dispute subject to payment of rent as might be fixed by the government from time to time.

facts.text: The government on May 2, 1947 modified its previous order directing that the appellants continue to retain possession of the land subject to payment of rent as fixed by the government.

anchor.surface_text: The government on May 2, 1947 modified its previous order by directing that the. appellants companyld companytinue to retain the possession of the land in dispute subject to payment of rent as might be fixed by the government from time to time.

facts.text: The respondent instituted suit for declaration that the government orders dated May 2, 1947 and March 1, 1949 were null, void and inoperative, for possession of the land, and for accounts of income.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon instituted suit for a declaration that the order of the government dated May 2,1947 and an ancillary order dated March 1, 1949 were null, void and inoperative. Prayer was also made that the appellants should remove all obstructions and hindrances from the land in dispute and should hand over the possession of the same to the respondent.

facts.text: The appellants resisted the suit claiming the government orders were administrative and no suit lay, and suit barred by limitation.

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the appellants on the ground that the impugned orders were administrative orders and numbersuit companyld lie for setting them aside. The suits were also stated to be barred by limitation.

facts.text: The trial court decreed the suit in favour of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt decreed the suit in favour of the respondent. On appeal the District Judge set aside the decreed in favour of the respondent.

facts.text: On appeal, the District Judge set aside the trial court's decree in favour of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the District Judge set aside the decreed in favour of the respondent. The decision of the District Judge was affirmed on second appeal by the High Court.

facts.text: The Gujarat High Court affirmed the District Judge's decision on second appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The decision of the District Judge was affirmed on second appeal by the High Court. The respondent then came up in appeal to this Court by special leave.

facts.text: This Court by judgment dated December 13, 1962 set aside the High Court and District Judge judgments and restored the trial court's decree for possession in favour of the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: This Court as per its judgment dated December 13, 1962, reported in,  1964  1 S.C.R. 200, accepted the appeal of the respondent and set aside the judgment of the High Court and the District Judge and restored that of the trial companyrt whereby decree for possession of the land in dispute had been awarded in favour of the respondent against the appellants.

facts.text: In 1960 the State of Bombay was bifurcated and the land became part of the State of Gujarat.

anchor.surface_text: In the meanwhile in 1960 the State of Bombay was bifurcated and the land in dispute which was earlier part of Bombay State became part of the State of Gujarat.

facts.text: The Gujarat Patel Watans Abolition Act, 1961 (Gujarat Act 48 of 1961) came into force on April 1, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: On April 1, 1963 the Act came into force. On July 19, 1966 the respondent filed an application to execute the, decree for possession of the land which-had been awarded in his favour.

facts.text: On July 19, 1966 the respondent filed an application to execute the decree for possession.

anchor.surface_text: On July 19, 1966 the respondent filed an application to execute the, decree for possession of the land which-had been awarded in his favour.

facts.text: The appellants objected that the decree had become inexecutable due to the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Objection was then taken by the appellants that the decree awarded in favour of the respondent had become inexecutable because of the companying into force of the Act.

facts.text: The executing court dismissed the execution application.

anchor.surface_text: This objection found favour with the executing companyrt which companysequently dismissed the execution application.

facts.text: The District Judge Bulsar dismissed the respondent's appeal against the executing court's order.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal filed by the respondent against the order of the executing companyrt was dismissed by the District Judge Bulsar.

facts.text: The Gujarat High Court allowed the respondent's second appeal, holding the respondent entitled to execute the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereafter filed second appeal before the Gujarat High Court. The High Court came to the companyclusion that the respondent was entitled to execute the decree for possession of the land obtained by him against the appellants.

facts.text: The Supreme Court is determining if the decree for possession awarded to respondent No. 1 Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar has become inexecutable after the Gujarat Patel Watans Abolition Act, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the decree for the possession of the land in dispute awarded in favour of Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar respondent No. 1  hereinafter described as the respondent has become inexecutable after the companying into force of the Gujarat Patel Watans Abolition Act, 1961  Gujarat Act 48 of 1961   hereinafter referred to as the Act  is the short question which arises for determination in this appeal brought by special leave against the judgment of the Gujarat High Court.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated the 3rd February, 1971 of the Gujarat High Court at Ahmedabad in Second Appeal No.639 of 1968.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 2(7), hereditary patelship means every village office of a revenue or police patel held hereditarily under the existing watan law for the performance of duties connected with the administration or collection of the public revenue of a village or with the village police, or with the settlement of boundaries or other matters of civil administration of a village and includes such office even where the services originally appertaining to it have ceased to be demanded.

anchor.surface_text: According to section 2(18). watan property means the movable or immovable property held, acquired or assigned under the existing watan law for providing remuneration for the performance of the duty appertaining to a hereditary patelship and includes a right under the existing watan law to levy customary fees or perquisites in money or in kind, whether at fixed times or otherwise and also includes cash payments in addition to the original watan property made voluntarily by the State Government and subject periodically,to motion or withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 gives, powers to the Collector, to decide various questions arising under the Act including the question whether any land is watan land and whether a person is, watandar or authorised holder or unauthorised holder. Right is also given to a person aggrieved by the order of the Collector to file appeal to the State Government

concepts.interpretation: Empowers Collector to decide questions under the Act; appeal to State Government.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: regranted to the watandar of the watan to which it appertained on payment by or on behalf of the wa

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 3 Gujarat Patel Watans Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: Section 4 has material bearing and reads as under Notwithstanding any usage or custom or anything contained in any settlement, grant, agreement, sanad, or any decree or order of a court or the existing watan law, with ,effect on and from the appointed day,- all patel watans shall be and are hereby abolished all incidents  including the right to hold office and watan property, the right to levy customary fees or perquisites in money or in kind, and the liability to render service  appertaining to the said watans shall be, and are hereby extinguished nooffice of patel shall be, hereditary and subject to the provisions of sections 6, 7 and 10 all watan land shall be and is hereby resumed and shall be subject to the payment of land revenue under the provisions of the Code and the rules made thereunder as if it were an unalienated land Provided that such resumption shall not affect the validity of any alienation of such watan land made in accordance with the provisions of the existing watan law or of the rights of an alienee thereof or any person claiming under or through him.

concepts.interpretation: Abolishes patel watans and incidents from appointed day, resumes watan land subject to ss 6,7,10; notwithstanding any decree etc., but does not render pre-existing decrees for possession inexecutable.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: on in section 4 of the Act On the execution of a decree for possession of the watan land obtained in favour of the watandar. The fact that patel watan

anchor.surface_text: Section 5 deals with resumption of watan land which is not a grant of soil and is held subject to a total or partial exemption from payment of land revenue thereof. We are, in the present case not concerned with such watan land.

concepts.interpretation: Deals with certain watan land not relevant here.

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 5 Gujarat Patel Watans Abolition Act

anchor.surface_text: According to section 6, watan land to which the provisions of section 5 do not apply shall, in cases not falling under section 7 or section 10 be regranted to the watandar of the watan to which it appertained on payment by or on behalf of the watandar to the State Government of the occupancy price equal to six times the amount of the full assessment of such land within the prescribed period and in the prescribed manner and the watandar shall be deemed to be occupant within the meaning of the Code in respect of such land and shall primarily be liable to pay land revenue to the State Government in accordance with the provisions of the Code and the rules made thereunder and all the provisions of the Code and the said rules relating to unalienated land shall subject to the provisions of this Act, apply to the said land.

concepts.interpretation: Regrants watan land to watandar on payment of occupancy price; watandar retains right to possession if complies.

anchor.surface_text: Section 7 deals with the regrant of watan land to authorised holders. According to the section, any watan land other than land to which the provisions of section 5 apply held by an authorised holder shall be regranted to him on payment by him or on his behalf to the State Government of the occupany price mentioned in section 6 and subject to the like conditions and consequences and all the provisions of section 6 shall apply mutatis mutandis in relation to the regrant of the, land under this section to the authorised holder as if were the watandar.

concepts.interpretation: Regrants to authorised holders similar to s6.

anchor.surface_text: Section 10 provides that where any watan land is in possession of an unauthorised holder, he shall be summarily evicted therefrom by the Collector in accordance with the provisions of the Code Provided that if the State Government is of opinion that in view of the investment made by such bolder in the development of the land or in the non- agricultural use of the land or otherwise, his eviction will cause undue hardship to him, it may direct the Collector to regrant the land to such holder on payment of such amount and subject to such terms and conditions as the State Government may determine and the Collector shall regrant the land accordingly.

concepts.interpretation: Evicts unauthorised holders but allows regrant if hardship.

concepts.interpretation: Saves pre-existing obligations, proceedings, remedies under watan incidents.

anchor.surface_text: It is a well established rule in construction of statutes that general terms following particular ones apply only to such persons or things as are ejusdem generis with those comprehended in the language of the Legislature,. In other words, the general expression is to be read as comprehending only,things of the same kind as that designated by the preceding particular expressions, unless there is something to show that a wider -sense was intended.  see p. 297 of Maxwell on the Interpretation of Statutes Twelfth Edition .

concepts.interpretation: Applies to interpret 'any decree or order of a court' in s4 as ejusdem generis with settlement, grant etc., not prohibiting execution of possession decrees.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: dispute in execution of the decree obtained by the respondent against them, the appellants can approach the State Government for regrant of the land i

concepts.unlisted_description: Rule of statutory interpretation limiting general words to same kind as specific preceding words.

issues.text: Whether the decree for the possession of the land in dispute awarded in favour of Laxman Purshottam Pimputkar respondent No. 1 hereinafter described as the respondent has become inexecutable after the coming into force of the Gujarat Patel Watans Abolition Act, 1961 (Gujarat Act 48 of 1961) hereinafter referred to as the Act

issues.text: whether the decree for possession of the land in dispute which was awarded in favour of the respondent has become inexecutable because of the coming into force of the Act

anchor.surface_text: The appellants have thereafter companye up in appeal to this Court by special leave. The question which arises for determination, as stated earlier, is whether the decree for possession of the land in dispute which was awarded in favour of the respondent has become inexecutable because of the companying into force of the Act.

issues.text: whether the right to execute the decree for the possession of watan land which has been obtained by the watandar against other persons comes to an end because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of all incidents appertaining to the said watans

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are companycerned is whether the right to execute the decree for the possession of watam land which has been obtained by the watandar against other persons companyes to an end because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of all incidents appertaining to the said watans.

issues.text: whether the appellants can claim regrant of the land under section 10 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: It is, in our opinion, number necessary for the purpose, of the present case to go into the question whether the appellants can claim regrant of the land under section 10 of the Act because this question does number materially affect the right of the respondent

issues.text: whether the words 'any decree or order of a court' in section 4 indicate that such decree or order cannot be executed

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made by Mr. Desai to the words any decree or order of a companyrt in the opening clause of section 4 of the Act. It is urged that those words indicate that the decree or order of a companyrt can also be number executed with effect from the appointed day.

arguments.claim: In view of section 4 of the Act, the decree for possession awarded to the respondent has become inexecutable because it was awarded in his capacity as watandar and patel watans have been abolished

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Dasai on behalf of the appellants has contended before us that in view of the provisions contained in section 4 of the Act, the decree for the possession of the land in dispute awarded in favour of the respondent has become inexecutable. it is submitted that as the decree was awarded in favour of the respondent in his capacity as a watandar and as patel watans have been abolished, the respondent cannot obtain the possession of the land to which he was entitled as a watandar

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ions of the Act. According to Mr. Desai, if the appellants are number dispossessed from the land in dispute in execution of the decree obtained by the

arguments.court_reasoning: Nothing in language of s4 renders such decrees inexecutable; legislature would have explicitly provided; abolition does not end right to possession; subject to ss6,7,10

arguments.claim: There is nothing in the language of section 4 which renders the decree for possession inexecutable

anchor.surface_text: This stand has been controverted by Mr. Patel on behalf of the respondent and he submits that there is nothing in the language of section 4 which renders the decree for the possession of the land in dispute inexecutable.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: on of statutes that general terms following particular ones apply only to such perso ns or things as are ejusdem generis with those companyprehended i

arguments.court_reasoning: There is nothing in the language of section 4 which renders such decrees for possession to be inexecutable

arguments.claim: The right to execute the decree and liability to hand over possession are kept intact by section 22 of the Act

anchor.surface_text: In any case, according to Mr. Patel, the right of the respondent to execute the decree and the liability of the appellants to hand over possession of the land to the respondent under the decree have been kept intact by section 22 of the Act.

arguments.court_reasoning: Not necessary to deal with alternative argument of s22

arguments.claim: The words 'any decree or order of a court' in section 4 indicate that such decree or order cannot be executed with effect from the appointed day
arguments.court_reasoning: Ejusdem generis rule applies; general terms follow particulars like settlement, grant etc., referring to things defining incidents of watans

arguments.claim: Decrees for possession of watan land obtained by watandar do not become inexecutable upon abolition under section 4

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are concerned is whether the right to execute the decree for the possession of watan land which has been obtained by the watandar against other persons comes to an end because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of all incidents appertaining to the said watans. The answer to this question, in our opinion, should be in the negative.

arguments.claim: Had legislature intended decrees for possession to become inexecutable, it would have incorporated such provision

anchor.surface_text: Had the legislature intended that the decrees for possession of the watan lands which had been obtained by the watandars against third persons should become inexecutable, the legislature would have indicated such an intention by incorporating some provision to that effect.

arguments.claim: Resumption under s4 does not affect right to possession as watandar entitled to regrant under s6

anchor.surface_text: Indeed, clause iv of section 4 of the Act expressly provides that the resumption of watan land consequent upon the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of incidents appertaining to the said watans would be subject to the provisions of sections 6, 7 and 10.

arguments.claim: Object of Act was to abolish feudal hereditary office but not deprive watandar of possession if conditions in s6 complied with

anchor.surface_text: The object of the Act as would appear from its preamble was to abolish patel watans because its hereditary character smacked of some kind of feudalism. At the same time, the legislature made it clear that it was not intended to deprive the watandar of the possession of the land if he complied with the conditions laid down in section 6 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Watandar has residual right to possession under s6 despite abolition

anchor.surface_text: It, therefore, cannot be said that there was a severance of all connections between the watandar and the watan land because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of incidents appertaining to such watans. A residual right was still there in the erstwhile watandar and that included the right to retain possession of watan land if the conditions mentioned in section 6 were complied with.

arguments.claim: Combined reading of ss4,6,7,10 shows watandar does not automatically lose possession right
Whether appellants can claim regrant under s10 not material to respondent's execution right
Opening clause of s4 uses ejusdem generis; 'any decree or order' refers to those defining watan incidents like settlements etc.
Impugned government orders were administrative and no suit lay; suit barred by limitation

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by the appellants on the ground that the impugned orders were administrative orders and no suit could lie for setting them aside. The suits were also stated to be barred by limitation.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: the appellants should render account of the income, of the land to the respondent. The suit was resisted by the appellants on the ground that the impu

arguments.court_reasoning: Previous SC judgment set aside lower courts and restored trial court decree in favour of respondent

holdings.text: The right to execute the decree for the possession of watan land which has been obtained by the watandar against other persons does not come to an end because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of all incidents appertaining to the said watans.

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are concerned is whether the right to execute the decree for the possession of watam land which has been obtained by the watandar against other persons comes to an end because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of all incidents appertaining to the said watans. The answer to this question, in our opinion, should be in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No explicit language in s4 prohibits execution of pre-existing possession decrees; legislature omitted any such provision; harmonious construction with ss6,7,10 shows watandar retains residual right to possession on compliance with regrant conditions; purposive intent abolishes feudal office but protects land possession.

holdings.text: There is nothing in the language of section 4 which renders such decrees for possession to be inexecutable.

anchor.surface_text: There is nothing in the language of section 4 which renders Such decrees for possession to be inexecutable. Had the legislature intended that the decrees for possession of the watan lands which had been obtained by the watandars against third persons should become inexecutable, the legislature would have indicated such an intention by incorporating some provision to that effect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain textual reading of s4 lacks any prohibition on executing possession decrees obtained prior to abolition.

holdings.text: A watandar on the abolition of patel watans and extinguishment of the incidents appertaining to the watans does not automatically lose his right to possession of the watan lands.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Combined reading of ss4,6,7,10; regrant provisions in ss6,7 preserve possession for watandar and authorised holders upon payment; contrast with eviction of unauthorised under s10; residual right post-abolition.

holdings.text: It is not necessary to decide whether the appellants can claim regrant of the land under section 10 of the Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue immaterial to respondent's right to execute decree against appellants.

holdings.text: The words 'any decree or order of a court' in the opening clause of section 4 do not indicate that such decree or order cannot be executed; they are ejusdem generis with preceding terms like settlement, grant, agreement, sanad defining watan incidents.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Ejusdem generis canon limits general phrase following specifics to same class: instruments defining/declaring watan incidents; does not override to prohibit decree execution.

anchor.surface_text: This Court as per its judgment dated December 13, 1962, reported in,  1964  1 S.C.R. 200, accepted the appeal of the respondent and set aside the judgment of the High Court and the District Judge and restored that of the trial companyrt whereby decree for possession of the land in dispute had been awarded in favour of the respondent against the appellants.

precedents.cited_proposition: Supreme Court accepted the appeal of the respondent, set aside the judgments of the High Court and District Judge, and restored the trial court's decree for possession of the land in dispute in favour of the respondent.
precedents.cited_holding: Decree for possession awarded in favour of the respondent against the appellants.

precedents.citation: Chhote Khan v. Mohammad Obedulla Khan 1

anchor.surface_text: Reference has been made by Mr. Desai to a Full Bench decision of Nagpur High Court in the case of Chhote Khan v. Mohammad Obedulla Khan 1 . It was held by the majority in that case that after the companying into force of the M.P. Abolition of Proprietary Rights  Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands  Act, 1950 the preemption decrees obtained by landlords are numberlonger executable because the persons seeking to enforce them have lost their proprietary interest.

precedents.case_name: Chhote Khan v. Mohammad Obedulla Khan
precedents.cited_proposition: After the coming into force of the M.P. Abolition of Proprietary Rights (Estates, Mahals, Alienated Lands) Act, 1950, the preemption decrees obtained by landlords are no longer executable because the persons seeking to enforce them have lost their proprietary interest.
precedents.cited_holding: Preemption decrees obtained by landlords are no longer executable post-abolition Act as landlords lost proprietary interest.

anchor.surface_text: The answer to this question, in our opinion, should be in the negative. There is numberhing in the language of section 4 which renders Such decrees for possession to be inexecutable. Had the legislature intended that the decrees for possession of the watan lands which had been obtained by the watandars against third persons should become inexecutable, the legislature would have indicated such an intention by incorporating some provision to that effect.

Section 7 regranting rights to authorised holders similar to s6 supports the holding that watandar does not automatically lose possession right upon abolition.
The saving clause in Section 22 for pre-existing obligations and remedies under watan incidents grounds the holding that the right to execute the decree for watan land does not end due to abolition.
Section 22 preserving pre-existing proceedings and remedies supports the holding that nothing in the Act (including section 4) renders such decrees inexecutable.
Section 22, which saves pre-existing obligations, proceedings, and remedies under watan incidents, addresses the issue of whether the pre-decree for possession has become inexecutable due to the Act.
Section 22, saving pre-existing remedies and proceedings, addresses the issue of whether the decree for possession has become inexecutable because of the Act.
The ejusdem generis interpretation grounds the holding that the words are limited to preceding matters and do not prohibit execution
Ejusdem generis application addresses the interpretive issue of whether the words prohibit execution of decrees or orders

The definition of 'watan' provides the foundational understanding necessary for the holding that distinguishes between extinguishment of watan incidents and retention of possession rights in watan lands.
The definition of 'watandar' in Section 2(16) supports the holding by providing the statutory basis for identifying the rights of the watandar post-abolition.

anchor.surface_text: The question with which we are concerned is whether the right to execute the decree for the possession of watam land which has been obtained by the watandar against other persons comes to an end because of the abolition of patel watans and the extinguishment of all incidents appertaining to the said watans. The answer to this question, in our opinion, should be in the negative.
